# HIRISE IMAGES 

![N|Solid](https://mars.nasa.gov/imgs/2009/07/mars-reconnaissance-orbiter-aerobreaking-PIA04917-br.jpg)

[![Build Status](https://travis-ci.org/joemccann/dillinger.svg?branch=master)](https://travis-ci.org/joemccann/dillinger)

This piece of software is used to get HIRISE images from NASA's PDS.


## Features

- Get specific information filtered by the mission phase, orbital range and the observation id
- Download images based on mission phase orbital range and the observation id
- Get specific metadata including - download size, number of images, label size etc

## Tech

HIRISE IMAGES  uses a number of open source projects to work properly:

- [BeautifulSoup4] - HTML enhanced for web apps!
- [progress-bar] - awesome web-based text editor


And of course HIRISEimgs itself is open source with a [public repository][dill]
 on GitHub.

## Installation

HIRISEimgs python [python](https://python.org/)  to run.

Install the dependencies and devDependencies and start the server.

```sh
cd HIRISEimgs
```

For production environments...

```sh

```

## Development

Want to contribute? Great!

Open your favorite Terminal and run these commands.

First Tab:

```sh
node app
```

Second Tab:

```sh
gulp watch
```

(optional) Third:

```sh
karma test
```

#### Building for source

For production release:

```sh
gulp build --prod
```

Generating pre-built zip archives for distribution:

```sh
gulp build dist --prod
```

## Docker

HIRISE IMAGES is very easy to install and deploy in a Docker container.

By default, the Docker will expose port 8080, so change this within the
Dockerfile if necessary. When ready, simply use the Dockerfile to
build the image.

```sh
cd HIRISEimgs
docker build -t <youruser>/HIRISEimgs:${package.json.version} .
```

This will create the HIRISEimgs image and pull in the necessary dependencies.
Be sure to swap out `${package.json.version}` with the actual
version of HIRISEimgs.

Once done, run the Docker image and map the port to whatever you wish on
your host. In this example, we simply map port 8000 of the host to
port 8080 of the Docker (or whatever port was exposed in the Dockerfile):

```sh
docker run -d -p 8000:8080 --restart=always --cap-add=SYS_ADMIN --name=HIRISEimgs <youruser>/HIRISEimgs:${package.json.version}
```

> Note: `--capt-add=SYS-ADMIN` is required for PDF rendering.

Verify the deployment by navigating to your server address in
your preferred browser.

```sh
127.0.0.1:8000
```
